author: Omar Rashid
text:
‘No party is in a position to defeat BJP on its own’

Buoyed by its big win in Bihar, the Janata Dal (United) is taking steps to forge an anti-BJP ‘grand alliance’ in Uttar Pradesh, which goes to the polls next year.

Bihar Chief Minister Nitish Kumar’s presence in Ghazipur, which abuts Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s constituency Varanasi, on Tuesday is a strong indication of the mobilisation of such an alliance in the State.

Mr. Kumar was the chief guest at the ‘Latia Mahotsav’, an annual function organised by a social organisation Samrat Ashok Club, to mark the birth anniversary of former Bihar Deputy Chief Minister, Babu Jagdev Prasad Kushwaha. With a strong Buddhist undertone to it, the function was heavily attended by members of the Most Backward Castes, in particular, Kushwaha, Nishad, Saini and Maurya.

Caste arithmetic

The JD(U) has already made overtures to some regional parties, Ajit Singh-led Rashtriya Lok Dal, the Peace Party and Apna Dal’s breakaway faction led by Krishna Patel, the wife of Kurmi leader Sone Lal Patel.

Through an alliance with the RLD, the JD(U) hopes to revive the Jat-Muslim combination, scarred by the 2013 Muzaffarnagar communal violence, in west U.P. While the Apna Dal commands support among Kurmis, a caste which Mr. Kumar belongs to, the Peace Party has Muslim support in pockets of Purvanchal.

“U.P. has more challenges than Bihar. Our fight is against the increasing communalism of the BJP. No party is in a position to defeat the BJP on its own,” JD(U) general secretary K.C. Tyagi told The Hindu .

It plans to forge an anti-BJP alliance in the poll-bound State
title: JD(U) plans to do a Bihar in U.P.
